page.title: 02Steeple Bumpstead.
page.content: Steeple Bumpstead is an extensive parish of nearly 400 acres.The main built up area of the village lies in the bottom of the valley of the {Bumpstead Brook,}a small tributary of the River Stour which runs from S.W. to N.E. through the parish to join the main river at Wixoe.The name Bumpstead or{"Bumstede"}as referred to in Domesday is thought to mean{"the place {where reeds grow"}and{Steeple}must refer to a{tower or steeple}which once existed in the village. Local tradition in the late 16th century suggested that the alternative name of {"Bumpstead at the Tower"}referred to {Roman ruins}somewhere north of the parish. A{folk poem}tells of the destruction of the steeple by a blizzard sent by an angry wizard to punish Bumpstead folk: "Once Steeple Bumpstead had a steeple, Beloved by
